item.title: Latest Push for Peace Is Zelensky’s Toughest Moment Since Start of War
item.description: The Ukrainian leader is trying to prepare his people for “a very difficult choice” after almost four years of full-scale conflict with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ian Lovett

item.title: Opinion | Trump Issues an Ultimatum to Ukraine
item.description: His latest peace offer fulfills Vladimir Putin’s wishes and leaves Kyiv with a terrible choice.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Trump’s Peace Plan for Ukraine, Annotated
item.description: Here’s a breakdown of some of the key points in the plan and how Ukraine and its European allies might respond.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Norman

item.title: Moody’s Ratings Upgrades Italy on Expectation of Declining Debt
item.description: The ratings agency boosted Italy one level to Baa2 and revised its outlook to stable from positive
item.dc:creator: Kelly Cloonan

item.title: Trump Says He Wants Ukraine’s Answer on Peace Plan by Thursday
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky says he faces “a very difficult choice.” Russian President Vladimir Putin says it could be the basis for a peace settlement.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Opinion | Why America Is a ‘Creedal Nation’
item.description: The distinguished historian says the U.S. isn’t like other nations and never has been. There is no American ethnicity to back up the state.
item.dc:creator: Gordon S. Wood

item.title: Opinion | Another Ukraine Peace Scare
item.description: It will take a lot more than what Donald Trump is doing to convince Putin that it’s in his best interest to stop.
item.dc:creator: Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.

item.title: Opinion | If the BBC Wants to Save Itself, Here’s an Idea
item.description: Robin Aitken, author of ‘The Noble Liar,’ offers some advice.

item.title: Jamie Dimon Threw King Charles a Birthday Party
item.description: The king didn’t actually attend, but celebrities and British nobility toasted the 77 year-old monarch at JPMorgan’s new headquarters
item.dc:creator: Alexander Saeedy

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince Leaves U.S. Tour Empowered on the Global Stage
item.description: President Trump sent a clear signal that he was elevating Mohammed bin Salman as an unmatched leader in the Arab world.
item.dc:creator: Sudarsan Raghavan

item.title: U.S. Pushes a Hamas-Free ‘Green Zone’ in Gaza
item.description: The U.S. is pushing ahead with plans to build communities for Palestinians on the Israeli side of the line dividing Gaza.

item.title: Trump Peace Plan Demands Major Concessions From Ukraine
item.description: The leaked proposal reveals Ukraine would have to cede territory, while Russia would receive incentives.

item.title: Europe Must Look Inward to Drive Growth, ECB’s Lagarde Says
item.description: The continent must move away from a growth model that is driven by exports, the European Central Bank president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Government Borrowing Runs Ahead of Plan as Budget Looms
item.description: Total borrowing for the first seven months of the fiscal year now stands at £116.8 billion, £9.9 billion above projections in March.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Japan Approves $135 Billion Stimulus Shot to Help Households, Economy
item.description: At the heart of the stimulus are measures to support households under financial strain, a key issue for Japanese voters.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: They Held a Climate Summit in the Amazon. They Didn’t Account for the Rain.
item.description: Heavy rain and intense heat have been among the disruptions at an annual United Nations climate conference being held this year in Belém, Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Yusuf Khan

item.title: The Web of Venezuelan Generals Accused of Fueling the Cocaine Trade
item.description: A diffuse group of officials and military men in Nicolás Maduro’s regime allow the drug to transit the country, U.S. officials say.

item.title: Opinion | Trump Says Arms Are Going to Taiwan
item.description: The first sale of his second term is an assist for Pacific deterrence.

item.title: Opinion | Railway Sabotage on a Polish Line to Ukraine
item.description: The authorities say the perpetrators acted at Russia’s direction.

item.title: U.S. Banks Shelve $20 Billion Bailout Plan for Argentina
item.description: Bankers are instead discussing a smaller, short-term facility to help Argentina make a roughly $4 billion debt payment in January.
item.dc:creator: Justin Baer

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Loosen Russia’s Grip on Serbia by Forcing Sale of Oil Company
item.description: The Abu Dhabi National Oil Company is in talks to buy Russia’s stake in energy behemoth NIS, according to an official U.S. document seen by The Wall Street Journal.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Why China Still Can’t Tolerate Christians and Other Believers
item.description: Recent arrests highlight Beijing’s deep ideological hostility to religious life, which flourishes even in the face of repression.

item.title: Cease-Fires in the Middle East Look a Lot Like War Anywhere Else
item.description: Israel is carrying out strikes as it loses patience with Hezbollah and Hamas’s resistance to disarming.

item.title: Swiss Watch Exports Continue on Downward Trend in U.S. Tariff Fallout
item.description: Total exports of the timepieces dropped 4.4% in October compared with the same period last year, driven by a U.S. slump.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Figueras

item.title: Pakistan’s Army Chief, Trump’s ‘Favorite Field Marshal,’ Cements Power
item.description: With a raft of constitutional changes, Asim Munir gets a new post and lifelong immunity from prosecution.

item.title: China Is Priming Its People and the World for a New Pressure Campaign on Taiwan
item.description: Beijing’s strategy, known as “the pen and the gun,” employs a domestic media campaign and aggressive rhetoric toward Taipei’s friends.

item.title: Maasai Sue Marriott Over Ritz-Carlton Safari Camp
item.description: Tribal leaders say the tourism development blocks one of the main migration routes of the Serengeti.

item.title: Trump Administration Pushes New Plan for Ending Ukraine War
item.description: The 28-point proposal drafted by some of the president’s closest aides is likely to face strong opposition from Ukraine.

item.title: Israel Asks ICC to Throw Out Netanyahu Warrant, Citing Allegations Against Prosecutor
item.description: Israel said in a court filing that Karim Khan may have been influenced by sexual assault accusations made by an aide.

item.title: U.S. Approves Deal to Sell AI Chips to Middle East
item.description: The agreement follows talks between President Trump and Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

item.title: Netherlands Suspends Order That Gave It Power Over Chinese-Owned Chipmaker Nexperia
item.description: The decision marks a step toward resolving a spat that had blocked vital chip supply to the auto industry.

item.title: Can Chinese-Made Buses Be Hacked? Norway Drove One Down a Mine to Find Out
item.description: The growing prevalence of Chinese technology in Europe’s infrastructure is stoking security concerns across the region.

item.title: Europe Aimed to Set Standards for Tech Rules, Now It Wants to Roll Them Back
item.description: Backed by France and Germany, the EU thinks easing back on legislation will boost growth and make the bloc less dependent on U.S. tech.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Wants American F-35s. Israel’s Success With Them Shows Why.
item.description: Israel has dominated battlefields across the Middle East for the past two years. A major reason is the F-35.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Russia With Atacms After Trump Lifted Long-Range Missile Ban
item.description: Kyiv acknowledged using the missile system, which relies on American intelligence for targeting.

item.title: Trump Sends Pentagon Officials to Ukraine in Effort to Restart Peace Talks
item.description: The push comes after the White House has seen multiple previous overtures to Moscow yield little progress on halting the war.

item.title: Bodies Keep Turning Up in Syria, Haunting New Leaders
item.description: In the months after the fall of the Assad regime, Syrians have continued to discover large-scale burial sites, sometimes by chance.

item.title: Canada Says Anglo American’s Pledges to Secure Teck Resources Deal Not Enough
item.description: Canada’s industry minister aims to deliver a decision next month on whether Anglo American can proceed with its takeover of Teck Resources, but warned that the British miner’s pledges to date aren’t enough.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Inside the Israeli-Linked Flights Carrying Palestinians Out of Gaza
item.description: A little-known organization that facilitates exits and takes payment in cryptocurrency has flown nearly 400 people out on three flights.

item.title: U.S. Supply Chains Deemed Vulnerable to Chinese Exploitation
item.description: Beijing could exploit the U.S.’s dependence on Chinese supply chains for products such as pharmaceuticals and electrical equipment, according to a new report to Congress.

item.title: The ‘JPMorgan Boys’ Behind the U.S. Bailout for Argentina
item.description: President Javier Milei’s administration is packed with former Wall Street traders trying to steer market forces.

item.title: Drug Kingpin Who Faked His Own Death and Fled Justice Runs Out of Luck
item.description: Wilmer Chavarria was arrested in Spain after running his alleged drug operation from abroad for four years.

item.title: Poland Says Rail Explosion Was ‘Unprecedented Act of Sabotage’
item.description: Prime Minister Donald Tusk said the goal of the sabotage was to blow up a train and that additional damage had been identified elsewhere on the route.
item.dc:creator: Karolina Jeznach

item.title: U.K. Follows Europe and U.S. in Crackdown on Asylum Seekers
item.description: Moves include threatening visa restrictions on countries that don’t take back failed asylum seekers, something President Trump has done.

item.title: The Nuclear-Arms Race Is Now a Three-Way Contest
item.description: Unlike during the Cold War, the U.S. must prepare for two peer rivals—Russia and China.

item.title: How American and Chinese Drone Arsenals Stack Up
item.description: A head-to-head comparison of unmanned aircraft shows the global rivals in a close race.

item.title: U.K. Assets Fall on Prospect of U-Turn on Government’s Income Tax Hike Plans
item.description: Sterling, U.K. government bonds and equities sold off on fresh concerns about fiscal sustainability ahead of the Nov. 26 budget.

item.title: China Registers Worst Investment Decline in Years as Slowdown Continues
item.description: Consumption also slowed, with retail sales on their longest run of decelerating growth since 2021.

item.title: Putin Is Turning Eighth-Grade Classrooms Into Army Training Grounds
item.description: A vast militarization of the education system is gathering pace in Russian classrooms, where students are trained to handle weapons by active soldiers.

item.title: Britain Is Preparing Tens of Billions in New Taxes—Again
item.description: The Labour government is readying its second major tax increase in two years as it tries to avoid spooking markets.

item.title: What the Looming Fall of a Ukrainian City Says About Putin’s War
item.description: The brutal fight for Pokrovsk points to the Russian leader’s aims and the problem with peace talks.

item.title: Pakistan Points Finger at India Over Suicide Blast
item.description: The accusation came as India’s prime minister vowed to find the perpetrators of a separate deadly explosion on Monday.

item.title: Car Explosion in India’s Capital Kills Eight
item.description: Indian officials said it was too early to say if the blast was the result of a bomb.

item.title: Bank of England Announces Proposals on Stablecoin Regulation
item.description: Under the BOE’s regime, individuals would be limited to owning up to 20,000 pounds of sterling-denominated systemic stablecoins, while businesses would be limited to holding up to 10 million pounds.

item.title: The Power of Gen Z Protesters Meets Lethal Force in Tanzania
item.description: Demonstrators have been protesting the cost of living and President Samia Suluhu Hassan’s tightening grip on power.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: A Truth Social Threat and a Scramble in Nigeria to Avert Military Action
item.description: The West African country is trying to persuade Trump not to insert the U.S. military or cut off aid as largely Muslim cattle herdsmen are accused of killing Christians.

item.title: Trump Administration Blocks Gunvor Takeover of Russian Oil Assets
item.description: The Swiss commodities trader pulled its offer after the Treasury Department said it opposed the deal.

item.title: Why a Song for Sad English Soccer Fans Is at the Center of a Fight Gripping Africa
item.description: Supporters of a deceased Zambian president have appropriated “Three Lions” in their campaign to bring his body home.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Trump Threatens Military Action in Nigeria in Defense of Christians
item.description: The president said the U.S. could go in “guns-a-blazing” to halt the perceived targeting of Christians by Islamist militants.

item.title: Will India and China Be Able to Resist U.S. Sanctions on Russian Oil?
item.description: New Delhi and Beijing have so far resisted U.S. calls to stop buying Russian crude, but far-reaching sanctions will be hard to ignore.
item.dc:creator: Jiahui Huang

item.title: Trump Signals Support for Selling Submarines to Australia
item.description: The president’s comments calmed fears that he would pull out of the Biden-era deal and came as he struck an agreement with the U.S. ally on rare earths.

item.title: How a Right-Wing Hindu Group Went From Fringe to Mainstream in India
item.description: India’s Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh group is stepping out of the shadows and flexing its power.

item.title: Trump Organization Expands in India, Where Many of Its Partners Face Accusations
item.description: Indian real-estate firms have been accused of fraud, money laundering and more on other projects. The Trumps have stepped up overseas deals in the president’s second term.

item.title: Pentagon Review of Aukus Security Pact Worries U.K., Australia
item.description: The review throws into doubt a strategic partnership that aims to give Australia nuclear-powered submarines and deter Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific.

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.

item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.

item.title: Russia’s Side Quest to Dominate Africa: Hijack a Videogame
item.description: Players in the ‘African Dawn’ videogame are asked to choose a side aligned with either Russia or the West.

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
